Michigan Initial Health & Safety Training Module A  
Section 3: Abusive Head Trauma; Shaken Baby Syndrome

What to Do to Soothe a Baby

Below are some ideas for soothing a baby.

1

Identify the Problem

First try to figure out what is bothering the baby.  If a baby is hungry, you may see signs like opening and closing her mouth, sucking or moving hands to her mouth or rooting (moving head back and forth looking for food). A tired baby may rub his eyes and or ears, yawn, close his fists, or make a jerky movement. If you can determine why the infant is crying, first try to fix the problem.

2

Relax the Baby

Try to help the baby relax. Soothing techniques may help. Babies like to suck. Moms can offer the breast; caregivers can offer bottles and pacifiers. Younger infants may respond to swaddling. Remember that licensing only allows swaddling in swaddle sacks and only up to 2 months old in child care sites. Turning the lights down can decrease the stimulation. Babies like sounds that mimic the womb, like a shushing sound or a vacuum. They also like soft music. Movement can also help, be it rocking, walking with the infant, or taking her for a stroller ride.

Keep in mind that even after all these techniques, there still will be times that you can’t get an infant to stop crying. If this happens and you find yourself frustrated, make the infant’s safety the top priority and take steps to calm yourself down.
